Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  ORDER  
This matter  is pending before Administrative Law Judge Megan J. McKenzie.  
On February 14, 2025, the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners (CPP -GIP) filed a motion to alleging that Citizens Utility Board 
(CUB) expert witness Scott Hempling breached the Court’s Highly Confidential Protective 
Order . CPP-GIP requests that the Court revoke Hempling’s access to Highly Confidential 
Trade Secret (HCTS) Information and strike the specific portions of Hempling’s testimony 
that include HCTS Information.  
On February 20, 2025, Hempling contacted the Office of Administrative Hearings 
and requested permission to file a letter explaining his actions.   
On February 25, 2025, CUB responded to the motion.  CUB does not contest that 
Hempling breached the Highly Confidential Protective Order and does not oppose the motion.  CUB has terminated its relationship with Hempling.  
Based upon the record  and the parties’ s ubmissions ,  
IT IS HEREBY ORDERED:  
1. Scott Hempling may file a letter, not to exceed three pages, responding to 
CPP-GIP’s motion by 4:30 p.m . on March 5, 2025.  
 2. Any party may file a response to Hempling’s letter,  not to exceed 
three pages, by 4:30 p.m . on March 7, 2025.  
 
Dated: March 3 , 2025  
 
 
MEGAN J. McKENZIE  
Administrative  Law Judge

1 
 March  3, 2025  
 
 The Honorable Megan J. McKenzie  
Administrative Law Judge  
Office of Administrative Hearings  
State of Minnesota  
 
      Docket No. E -015/PA -24-198 
      OAH Docket No. 25 -2500- 40339 
 
Dear Judge McKenzie,  
 
I understand that you have received in this docket one or more submissions relating to my 
handling of highly confidential material.  I write this letter not to contest those submissions —
which I have not read—but only to summarize the facts in one place, to acknowledge my role in the situation, and to make clear that I accept the consequences that you or the Commission establish.  I have filed this letter consistent with your law clerk ’s instructions  received today .   
 
The confidential version of my testimony included quotes from HCTS materials. This 
letter describes events relating to that testimony, as best as I can remember them.  I have disclosed all these facts to GIP ’s counsel . 
 
My client filed my testimony with the Commission on February 4, 2025.  My client  then 
emailed me both the public version and the HCTS version—the latter, it turned out, having a filename in which the client had inadvertently included the word PUBLIC.  On February 5, I 
posted the document whose filename included “ PUBLIC ” to my professional website.  On the 
evening of February 6, I posted on LinkedIn a link to that file on my website.  About 15 minutes later, I learned from my counsel that this file labeled PUBLIC was in fact the HCTS file.  I learned of that fact so soon af ter my LinkedIn posting because, coincidentally, my counsel saw 
my LinkedIn post just after I made it and immediately contacted me about the labeling error.  I immediately had my assistant take the LinkedIn post down; she then removed the file  from my 
webs ite.  I also then posted a message on LinkedIn stating that anyone who had accessed the file 
should delete it and contact me immediately.  I have heard from no one.   
 
My counsel notified GIP ’s counsel of these facts the next day.  According to LinkedIn, 
my second post  (the post saying to take the file down) had about 350 “impressions.”   I don’ t 
know how many impressions the original post (the one with the link to the file  on my website ) 
because I deleted that post —as indicated, as soon as I learned of the problem and only 15 
minutes after I ’d posted it —and didn’ t think at that time to look for the number of impressions.  
 
WWW .SCOTTHEMPLINGLAW .COM 
 
 
2 
 (I believe that an “ impression ” means that someone saw the second post, not that someone 
downloaded the document.)  At the request of GIP’s counsel, relayed to me by my counsel, I 
removed the  second post ; i.e., the one that  that had alerted LinkedIn visitors to delete the file and 
to contact me.  
 
On February 5 around 1.40pm, I had sent the same mislabeled file to two colleagues who 
share an interest in the subject.  When I learned of labeling error, I instructed them by email to 
delete the document.  Both confirmed, by email February 7, that they had deleted the file and that 
they had not opened the file.   
The day after I learned of the error, I instructed my assistant, at GIP counsel ’s request, to 
contact GoDaddy, the company that hosts my website.  The purpose was to see if they could tell us about any downloads of the file from my website.  GoDaddy told my assistant that they do not have that capability.  GoDaddy recommended software for us to try.  My assistant tried the 
software but determined that it tracked downloads only prospectively.  I informed my counsel of this fact, which he then transmitted to GIP ’s counsel. 
 
The above discussion addresses my actions concerning the mislabeled file.  
 
For this 140- page document I had three assistants.  Two were proofreaders and one was a 
formatting expert.  They had access to the HCTS version of my testimony for a few days before I sent it to my client for filing on February 4, 2025.  They had no access to any HCTS material other than what was in my testimony.  I myself never downloaded any  HCTS material but rather 
read it from the source website.  
 
One of my proofreaders lacked a personal printe r—a fact that I did not know when I sent 
her the file for proofing.  When I informed her of the labeling error, I learned that to carry out the proofing task, she had emailed it to a nearby Federal Express office to have it printed there.  
 
I have disclosed all the above facts to GIP ’s counsel.  
 
Though my client informed GIP of the posting error the day after we discovered it, I 
didn’ t inform my client and GIP of my internal helpers ’ access until later.  I was focused on the 
potential disclosure to the publ ic via my website and LinkedIn; that was the concern as it was 
initially related to me from GIP.  It hadn ’t occurred to me at the time that there would be a 
concern with my having my clerical assistants see the document , because it is my regular 
practice, and I assume the practice of other professionals, to use assistants to proof and format 
my work, subject to my internal office requirement to maintain the confidentiality of that work.  Therefore I did not think to tell GIP that my assistants had had acces s to the document.  It was 
when GIP asked me about others ’ access that I explained my assistants ’ access.   
 
There was then a followup questionnaire from GIP, forwarded by my counsel late 
afternoon on Friday February 14, asking me more specifics.  I wrote answers early the next morning (Saturday, February 15) and then emailed them to my counsel for him to forward to GIP.  Because of t he three- day weekend, my counsel and I did not connect until late afternoon of 
Tuesday, February 18.  At that time we agreed that he would send my February 15 summary to 
 
WWW .SCOTTHEMPLINGLAW .COM 
 
 
3 
 GIP’s counsel.  Early on February 19, I decided it was better to do so myself, and I so informed 
my counsel.  I then reviewed my February 15 summary, added some details that I had not 
remembered when I wrote the February 15 draft, and emailed it to GIP ’s counsel.  On February 
20, I added one more fact to the document and emailed it GIP ’s counsel.  That additional fact 
was that I  had forgotten, until the evening of February 19, to instruct one of my proofers to delete 
the document . 
 
The foregoing is my best memory of how I handled my assistants ’ access to the 
document.  
Here are additional facts, presented here for completeness.    
 
• My counsel informed me February 18 that in one of my emails to him to which I attached a confidential version of my testimony, I had cc -ed his Executive Director, 
who had not signed the NDA.  My understanding is that the Executive Director did not open the document.  
 
• I have deleted from my computer all confidential testimony in the proceeding, including my own confidential testimony.  I have not opened any of the confidential testimony submitted by others. 
 
• The only conversations in which I discusse d the confidential material were 
conversations with my client.  
  
In summary:  I appreciate this opportunity to present the facts as I remember them.  I will of course accept the consequences.  
  Sincerely,  
 
 
 Scott Hempling

Response in Support of DOC Motion to Compel Discovery and Lift HCTS Designations
content:
BEFORE THE MINNESOTA OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS  
600 North Robert Street  
St. Paul, Minnesota 55101 
 
FOR THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
121 7th Place East  
Suite 350 
St. Paul, Minnesota  55101- 2147 
 
Katie Sieben  Chair  
Joseph K. Sullivan  Vice C hair 
Hwikwon Ham  Commissioner  
Audrey Partridge  Commissioner  
John Tuma  Commissioner  
 
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota  
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by  
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
and Global Infrastructure Partners  OAH File No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No . E-015/PA -24-198 
 
RESPONSE OF THE OFFICE  OF  
THE ATTORNEY GENERAL — 
RESIDENTIAL UTILITIES DIVISION   
TO THE DEPARTMENT’S  MOTION TO 
COMPEL  DISCOVERY AND LIFT 
HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE 
SECRET  DESIGNATIONS  
 
The Office of the Attorney General —Residential Utilities Division (OAG) submits this 
response to the Minnesota Department of Commerce’s m otion to compel discovery from Global 
Infrastructure Management LLC  (GIP)  and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP) 
(collectively, “Partners”)  and to lift highly confidential trade secret (HCTS) designations from a 
document produced by the Partners .  
As the Department demonstrates  in its memorandum and declaration supporting its motion, 
the Partners have withheld information that the parties to this proceeding are entitled to review by 
redact ing information , based on unsupported claims of privilege , within documents  that are 
already  designated as HCTS .  They have also designated as HCTS  certain information that does 
not meet the standard set out in the Administrative Law Judge’s HCTS Protective Order.   
2 
 The information that the Department seeks to compel  is also relevant to the testimony of 
OAG witness Brian Lebens ,1 and the OAG therefore has an interest in its disclosure.  The OAG 
also has an interest in transparency and believes the public should have access to the type of 
information in Ex. DOC -___, SLV -D-6 that can show the risks and benefits of the proposed 
transaction.  By designating this entire document as HCTS, Partners have attempted to prevent the 
public from understanding the full implications of the transaction.  
Regarding the Partners’ claims of privilege, a s the Department’s motion, declaration, and 
attachments describe in detail, the context of many of the redactions show that the claimed legal advice appears to simply be future business plans.
2  Notably, the redactions provided on the basis 
of privilege are internally inconsistent , where some pages are marked privileged and others are 
not.3  Yet the Partners claim privilege applies to all.4  This lack of consistency draws into question 
the validity of the privilege claims.  
The OAG also supports the Department’s request to remove the HCTS designation from 
Ex. DOC -___, SLV -D-6 and make the document public. In this proceeding, the Commission is 
tasked with determining whether the transaction is in the public interest.5  The extensive and 
unsupported designations of information as HCTS  unjustifiably withholds information from the 
public about items that concern their interests.  
The Partners ’ unjustifiable withholding of information from the Department, OAG , 
intervening parties, and the Commission based on unsupported claims of privilege prevents the 
public -interest advocates and Commission from determining  whether the transaction’s benefits 
 
1 See Direct Testimony of Brian Lebens at Schedule 8.  
2 See Memorandum Supporting Motion to Compel at 6- 7.  
3 Compare  Decl. of Katherine Arnold, Ex. G -38–G-39 to  id., Ex. G -40–G -44.  
4 See Decl. of Katherine Arnold, Ex. J -4.  
5 Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, subd. 1.  
3 
 will outweigh its costs.  And the vast amount of trade secret and HCTS designations by the Partners 
clouds the public’s view into the Commission’s public- interest determination.  What the Partners’  
extensive redactions and refusal to turn over information does achieve is provide a foretaste of the 
likely future regulatory battles that public -interest advocates may face if the transaction is 
approved.  
The OAG requests that Your Honor grant the Department’s request to allow the parties and 
Commission to review all relevant, non -privileged information to determine whether the 
transaction is in the public interest and allow the public to review relevant information about the 
Partner s’ future plans for Minnesota Power and the impact of those plans on Minnesotans.   
 
Dated:   February 28, 2025 Respectfully submitted,  
 
KEITH ELLISON  
State of Minnesota Attorney General  
 
/s/Katherine Hinderlie   
KATHERINE HINDERLIE

Additional Info: LPI Response in Support of Department of Commerce Motion
content:
1 BEFORE THE MINNESOTA OFFICE OF  
ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS  
600 North Robert Street  
P.O. Box 64620 
St. Paul, MN  55101  
 
FOR THE PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
OF THE STATE OF MINNESOTA  
121 Seventh Place East, Suite 350 
St. Paul, MN  55101- 2147 
 
Katie Sieben  Chair  
Joseph Sullivan Vice Chair  
Hwikwon Ham  Commissioner  
Audrey Patridge  Commissioner  
John Tuma  Commissioner  
 
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners  
  
PUC Docket No. E -015/PA -24-198 
OAH File No. 25 -2500- 40339 
 
RESPONSE  IN SUPPORT OF 
DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE  
MOTION TO COMPEL  
 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION  
Pursuant to Minn. R. 1400.6600, the Large Power Intervenors1 (“LPI”) hereby file this 
response in support of the Minnesota Department of Commerce’s (“Department”) Notice of and 
Motion to Compel Discovery and Lift HCTS Designations  (“Motion”) , filed in the above -
caption ed docket on February 13, 2025.2  LPI supports the Department’s Motion because (1) the 
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  (“Commission”)  has directed development of a full record 
regarding “potential harms to the public interest from the proposed transaction, including in 
 
1 LPI is an ad hoc consortium of Large Power and Large Light and Power customers of Minnesota Power consisting 
for purposes of this filing of Blandin Paper Company; Boise Paper, a Packaging Corporation of America company, 
formerly known as Boise, Inc.; Cleveland- Cliffs Minorca Mine Inc.; Enbridge Energy, Limited Partnership; Gerdau 
Ameristeel US Inc.; Hibbing Taconite Company; Sappi Cl oquet, LLC; USG Interiors, Inc.; United States Steel 
Corporation (Keetac and Minntac Mines); and United Taconite, LLC.  
2 In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment 
Board and Global Infrastructure Partners , MPUC Docket No. E -015/PA -24-198 and OAH File No. 25- 2500 -40339, 
Notice of and Motion to Compel Discovery (February 13, 2025) (eDocket No. 20252 -215370- 01). 
2  relation to cost or risk,”3 and (2) the continued efforts of Global Infrastructure Management LLC 
and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (collectively, “Partners”) at redaction, combined with 
an unwillingness to produce standard privilege logs, underscore the significant risk that the 
Partners will not be transparent and will rebuff each attempt to make reasonable disclosures.  For 
these reasons, LPI supports the Department’s contention that the Partners have inappropriately 
imposed “Highly Confidential Trade Secret” (“HCTS”) restrictions on multiple discovery 
responses, where such designations are not supported, and its request that the Administrative Law Judge order  the Partners to (1) make Ex. DOC -___, SLV -D-6 (“DOC IR SUPP 0011.01 
Attach”)  public, and (2) provide unredacted copies of documents responsive to DOC IR Nos. 
13 and 60.  
II. LEGAL STANDARD
Minn. R. 1400.6600 directs that for any motion made to the judge for an order shall 
advise that other parties should “file a written response with the judge and service cop ies on 
all parties, within ten working days after it is received.”
4  
III. ANALYSIS
A) The Commission Has Directed, Not Recommended, Record Development on Cost
and Risk.
In its October 7, 2024, Order Requiring Additional Information and Granting
Intervention, and Notice of and Order for Hearing (“October Order”), the Commission stated 
its expectation for development of a full record to address certain issues, first and foremost  
covering “any potential harms to the public interest from the proposed transaction, including 
in relation to cost or risk.”5  In an effort to comply with the Commission’s directi ve, parties 
submitted discovery requests to the Partners aimed  to better understand how the financial  
information and investment plans compiled by the Partners , which form core cost -related 
components of the Acquisition impact ing ratepayers, will impact costs ultimately passed on 
3 In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment 
Board and Global Infrastructure Partners , Order Requiring Additional Information and Granting Intervention, and 
Notice of and Order for Hearing at 8 (October 7, 2024)  (“October Order”) . 
4 Minn. R. 1400.6600.   Although the timeframe appears limited to those parties contesting a motion, LPI submits this 
response in support of the Motion within the same referenced timeframe.   
5 October Order at 8.  
3  to consumers in the form of increased rates (i.e., DOC IRs 11, 13, and 60).6  Despite  parties’ 
attempts to gain insight into this critical information, the Partners have taken an overzealous 
approach to redacting  responses to DOC IRs 11, 13, and 60, effectively  hiding pertinent 
information related to the Partners’ valuation of ALLETE and Minnesota Power, which 
presumably impacts the Partners’ investment decision .  Such redaction eliminate s parties’ 
ability to  effectively  discuss that financial and investment  information during either 
evidentiary hearings before the Administrative Law Judge or oral argument  and deliberations 
before the Commission .  Such arbitrary redaction contravenes the Commission’s explicit 
direction to conduct transparent and open record development on cost and risk and represents 
improper application of HCTS redaction on the part of the Partners.   The record development 
required by the Commission simply cannot coexist with  the overzealous redaction advanced 
by the Partners.   As such, LPI supports the Department’s request that the Administrative Law 
Judge direct the Partners to make DOC IR SUPP 0011.01 Attach public and provide 
unredacted copies of documents responsive to DOC IR Nos. 13 and 60. 
B) Partners ’ Inappropriate Redactions Underscore Significant Concerns About
Transparency  and Their  Willingness to  Make Reasonable Disclosures.
Proceeding from the Partners’ continued efforts to inappropriately redact  non- HCTS
financial and investment information, combined with their unwillingness to produce standard 
privilege logs, LPI harbors significant concerns regarding the veracity of the Partners’ claims 
regarding transparency.  The Partners unwillingness to make reasonable disclosures at this stage 
of the proceeding indicates a pattern of behavior that contravenes the rules of discovery7 and the 
spirit of the regulatory compact.  LPI is also troubled by the Partners’ aggressive behavior in 
seeking to strike portions of testimony from the Citizens Utility Board (“CUB”) that should not 
6 DOC IR 11 requests all contracts, agreements, etc. between all entities involved or related to GIP Fund V and Tower 
Bridge .  DOC IR 13 requests complete copies of any analyses GIP has conducted to value ALLETE or Minnesota 
Power.  DOC IR 60 requests copies of analyses CPP Investments has conducted related to the value of ALLETE or 
Minnesota Power, as well as any reports and/or presentations related to its valuation and decision to invest in ALLETE.  
7 See Minn. R. Civ. P. 26.  
4  only be public but are also presumably axiomatic , while simultaneously seeking to limit witness 
access to testimony.8    
Without accountability at this stage of the proceeding, it is reasonable to assume that the 
Partners will continue to undermine statutorily -directed rules of discovery  and the directi ves of the 
Commission , while hiding  the true cost impacts of the Acquisition, to the detriment of ratepayers . 
Further, ma ny ratepayer benefits that the Partners argue will be realized as a result of the 
Acquisition (not that LPI believes any exist) hinge on levels of transparency and trust that the 
Partners appear unwilling and unable to uphold.  When the Partners shun the opportunity to be 
transparent and make reasonable disclosures at the earliest stages of the proceeding, LPI and other ratepayer representatives have no choice but to interpret that behavior as an indication of how the 
Partners wi ll act in the future and  as foreshadowing of the Partners’ intent to fight disclosure at 
every opportunity.  In short, the Partners’ actions speak much louder than the words from their 
counsel.  LPI urges action now to compel production of the public infor mation in DOC IR SUPP 
0011.01 Attach, as well as the provision of unredacted copies of documents responsive to DOC IR Nos. 13 and 60, so that parties may conduct the Commission- direct ed record 
development. 
III. CONCLUSION
LPI respectfully submits th is response in support of the Department’s Motion to ensure 
that the Partners are held accountable to the levels of transparency and reasonable disclosure required to proceed through this docket, and to comport with the requirements of the Commission’s 
October Order.  
8 In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment 
Board and Global Infrastructure Partners , MPUC Docket No. E- 015/PA -24-198 and OAH File No. 25- 2500 -40339 , 
Notice of Motion and Motion to Revoke Access and strike Direct Testimony of Scott Hempling (February 14, 2025) 
(eDocket No. 20252- 215428- 02).  While CUB may have elected to no longer offer this testimony, it is reasonably 
clear that CUB worked swiftly and in good faith to address the disclosures.  In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners , 
MPUC Docket No. E- 015/PA -24-198 and OAH File No. 25 -2500- 40339 , Letter (February 10, 2025) (eDocket No. 
20252- 215160- 01). 
5 D
ated:  February 27, 2024 Respectfully submitted, 
STOEL RIVES LLP 
/s/ Andrew P. Moratzka 
Andrew P. Moratzka (#0322131) 
Amber S. Lee (#0342178) 
Eden A. Fauré (#0403824) 
33 South Sixth Street Suite 4200 Minneapolis, MN  55402 Tele: (612) 373-8800 Fax:  (612) 373-8881 
AT
TORNEYS FOR THE LARGE POWER 
INTERVENORS

332 Minnesota Street, Suite W1360  
Saint Paul, MN 55101 
www.cubminnesota.org  
info@cubminnesota.org, 651 -300- 4701  
 
 
 
February 25, 202 5 
 
The Honorable Megan J. McKenzie  
Administrative Law Judge  
Office of Administrative Hearings  
PO Box 64620  St. Paul, MN 55164 -0620  
 
Re: 
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
and Global Infrastructure Partners  MPUC Docket No . 
E-015/PA -24-198 
E-015/M -24-383 
 
Dear Judge McKenzie:  
 Please find attached CUB’s response the Motion to Revoke Access and Strike Direct Testimony 
of Scott Hempling filed on February 14, 2025. Also attached is a not-public HCTS  Declaration 
of Brian Edstrom. Because most of the  Declaration discusses information that the Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Management, LLC  have identified 
as trade secret and/or highly confidential trade secre t, the De claration  is filed only in Docket 
E-015/M -24-383.  
 I have also  email ed a copy of both documents to th e desi gnated counsel or represen tative for 
each party in this proceeding.  
 
Sincerely,  
 /s/ Brian Edstrom    
Brian Edstrom  
Senior Regulatory Advocate  
Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota  
651-300-4701, ext. 6  
briane@cubminnesota.org   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
332 Minnesota Street, Suite W1360  
Saint Paul, MN 55101 
www.cubminnesota.org

CERTIFICATE OF SERVICE  
 
I, Brian Edstrom, hereby certify that I have served by electronic filing  or electronic mail  a true

1. CUB ’s response the Motion to Revoke Access and Strike Direct Testimony of Scott 
Hempling filed on February 14, 2025  to all persons at the addresses indicated on the 
attached service lists; and  
 
2. The not-public HCTS Declaration of Brian Edstrom to all persons at the addresses 
indicated on the attached service list for D ocket  No. E-015/M -24-383 and the

Response of the Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota to  
 Motion to Strike and Revoke Access  
 
 
On February 14, 2025, attorneys for Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Management, LLC (collectively, “Partners”) ﬁled a motion  (the “Partners’ Motion”)  to 
revoke access and strike the Highly Conﬁdential Trade Secret version of the direct testimony of Scott 
Hempling . Pursuant to Minnesota Rule 1400.6600 , the Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota (“CUB”) 
hereby responds  to the Partners’ Motion.  For the reasons discussed below, CUB does not oppose 
Partners’ Motion ; however, CUB wishes to respond and add context to certain a spects of it.  
 
1.) CUB no longer intends to oﬀer Mr. Hempling’s pre -ﬁled testimony into the evidentiary 
record.  
 
CUB entered into a consulting agreement with Scott  Hempling , eﬀective as of September 25, 
2024  (“Consulting Agreement”) , so that Mr. Hempling could assist us in reviewing  the Petition ﬁled in 
this proceeding .1 On February 18, 2025, CUB  and Mr. Hempling mutually agreed to terminate the 
 
1 See attached Declaration of Brian Edstrom at ¶ 3.  
   
 
 2  
 Consulting Agreement, with such termination eﬀective as of 5:00pm CST that day .2 For this reason, 
CUB no longer intends to oﬀer Mr. Hempling’s pre -ﬁled direct testimony into the evidentiary record 
in this matter. We  a l s o  d o  n o t  i n t e n d  f o r  M r .  H e m p l i n g  t o  p r e p a r e ,  o r  f o r  C U B  t o  ﬁ l e ,  rebuttal or  
surrebuttal testimony from Mr. Hempling.   
Pursuant to Paragraph 23 of Your Honor’s First Prehearing Order, “pre -ﬁled testimony that is 
not oﬀered into the record [. . .] shall be considered withdrawn and no witness shall be cross-
examined concerning the withdrawn testimony.”3 CUB will respect and comply with whatever  other  
actions Your Honor ﬁnds are warranted to resolve this matter.  
 
2) We disagree the public version of Mr. Hempling’s Direct Testimony originally ﬁled on February 
4, 2025 breaches the HCTS Protective Order.  
 
The Partner’s suggest “Hempling’s Direct Testimony contains a substantial amount of [Highly 
Conﬁdential Trade Secret (“ HCTS ”)] Information”  and implies that CUB/Mr. Hempling breached the 
HCTS Protective Order  when ﬁling the public version of Mr. Hempling’s Direct Testimony on February 
4, 2025.4 We disagree with this characterization of CUB’s February 4, 2025 ﬁling.  
On February 4, 2025, CUB ﬁled a public version of Mr. Hempling’s direct testimony in Docket 
24-198 and a not -public HCTS version of Mr. Hempling’s direct testimony in HCTS Docket No. M -24-
383. The public version of Mr. Hempling’s direct testimony redacted certain information that one or more of the Petitioners had identiﬁed as HCTS. Such redactions appeared on 2 out of 146 pages and 
7 out of 176 footnotes of Mr. Hempling’s Direct Testimony.
5  
A memorandum of law ﬁled with  Partner’s Motion  states  that “the Partners determined that 
both footnote 8 and 9, on page, 6 [of Mr. Hempling’s Direct Testimony] included public references to 
 
 
2 Id. at ¶ 27.  
 
3 In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners, First Prehearing Order, OAH 25- 2500- 40339; MPUC Docket E -015/PA -24-198 (Oct. 28, 2024),  ¶ 23, Doc. 
Id. 202410- 211370- 01. 
 
4 In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global  
Infrastructure Partners, Memorandum of Law in Support of Motion to Revoke Access and Strike Direct Testimony of Scott 
Hempling, Docket No. E -015/PA -24-198 (Feb. 14, 2025)  (“Partners’ Memorandum”) , p. 6.  
 
5 See generally, In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment B oard 
and Global Infrastructure Partners , Direct Testimony of Scott Hempling, Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 (Feb. 4, 2025, erratum ﬁled 
Feb. 6, 2025) (“Hempling Direct”), Doc. Id 20252- 215065- 02. 
 
   
 
 3  
 the content of HCTS documents”  and that “[t]he Partners were compelled to contact CUB and request 
that the testimony be withdrawn and replaced by a version properly redacted. ”6 As noted in our 
February 6, 2025  letter  ﬁled in this docket ,7 CUB disagreed  that the original public version of Mr. 
Hempling’s direct testimony required additional redaction to remove  HCTS information  from these 
two footnotes.  Nevertheless, CUB honored the Partners’ request to re -ﬁle the public version of Mr. 
Hempling’s direct testimony with minor changes to what was redacted in the original version. A full 
description of th ese minor changes, along with an explanation of CUB’s decision to not redact certain 
information from the original public version of Mr. Hempling’s testimony, is included in the attached HCTS Declaration  of Brian Edstrom.  
 
3) CUB acted in g ood faith to disclose and address the disclosure of HCTS information .  
 
The memorandum attached to Partners’ Motion includes a description of facts the Partners 
“believe to be true”  based on information provided by CUB.8 CUB has, indeed, provided information 
to the Partners based on knowledge available to us at the time such information was provided. 
Attached here is a HCTS Declaration of Brian Edstrom, CUB’s Senior Regulatory Advocate, reporting  
our understanding of what led to the disclosure of HCTS information on February 6, 2025 and the actions  CUB took following that disclosure to provide information to the Partners.  CUB has acted in 
good faith to comply with both protective orders  issued  in this proceeding to address the unfortunate 
incident described in the Partners’ Motion.  
  
 
  
 
 
6 Partners’ Memorandum at 6.  
7 See generally, In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment B oard 
and Global Infrastructure Partners , CUB Letter, Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 (Feb. 6, 2025), Doc. Id. 20252- 215065- 01 
 
8 Partners’ Memorandum at 7. 
   
 
 4  
 As noted above, CUB does not oppose the Partners’ Motin to Strike and Revoke Access, and 
we intend to not oﬀer Mr. Hempling ’s pre -ﬁled direct testimony into the evidentiary record. We will 
respect and comply with whatever  further  actions Your Honor ﬁnds are warranted to resolve this 
matter.

  The Commission met on Thursday,  September 19, 2024,  with Chair Sieben and Commissioners 
Means, Ham , Sullivan, and Tuma present.  
 The following matters were taken up by the Commission:  
 
 
P-999/CI- 18-382 
In the Matter of a Commission Inquiry to Examine Streamlining Procedures for Consent Dockets  
 
Commissioner Tuma  moved that the Commission do the following:  
 
1. Find that the rule variance requirements of Minn. R. 7829.3200 are met and extend the 
variances of Minn R. 7811.0200, 7812.0200, and 7829.1400 as described in the Commission’s Order Varying Comment Periods in Certain Uncontested Dockets (November 5, 2018).  
 
2. Find that the rule variance requirements of Minn. R. 7829.3200 are met and add Emergency Plan – 911 Plan (EP) dockets to the list of telecommunication docket types to 
which these rule variances apply.  
 
3. Grant a variance for a length of time as determined by the Commission.  
 The motion passed 5–0. 
  P-999/PR -24-8 
In the Matter of Annual Certification Related to Eligible Telecommunications Carriers’ (ETCs) Use of the Federal Universal Service Support Required Pursuant to C.F.R. 54.313  
 Commissioner Tuma  moved that the Commission do the following:  
 
1. Certif y that all companies within the state indicated in Tables 1, 2, and 4 of Attachment 
A of the staff briefing papers used in the preceding calendar year, and will be used in the coming calendar year, all federal high -cost support provided to them only for the 
provision, maintenance, and upgrading of facilities and services for which the support is 
intended, pursuant to 47 C.F.R. § 54.314.  
 
2. Provide the Universal Service Administrative Company with a list of carriers (including 
their Study Area Code s) from Table 4 that should be certified by letter to the Federal 
Communications Commission  (FCC).  
2 | Page  3. Continue to require all recipients of high -cost funding to share Performance Measure 
Testing results annually in  all future filings of FCC Form 481.  
 
4. Require each  eligible telecommunications carrier (ETC ) receiving support pursuant to the 
high -cost program that ha s not reached 100% compliance with Performance Measure 
Testing goals in the latest reported quarter to file quarterly results with the Minnesota 
Public Utilities Commission  until the noncompliant ETC reaches 100% compliance . 
 
5. Continue to require quarterly filings of Tribal engagement from the ETCs consistent with 
the requirements in the Commission’s Order Certifying Eligible Telecommunications Carriers’ Use of Federal High -Cost Subsidy ( October 21, 2021) , in Docket P -999/PR -21-8, 
and Order Recertifying Eligible Telecommunications Carriers and Setting Additional 
Requirements ( November 8, 2022) in Docket No. P -999/PR -22-8. 
 
6. Require carriers that were recipients of high- cost funding during the year 2023 to 
submit their Lifeline Best Practices compliance filings in compliance with the 
Commission’s Order Establishing Best Practices and Requiring Filings ( July 20, 2021 ) in 
Docket No. P -999/CI -20-747, In the Matter of a Commission Inquiry into the Advertising, 
Outreach, and Offering of Lifeline by High- Cost ETCs , by December 31, 2025. These 
compliance filings should be filed electronically in Docket No. P -999/CI -20-747.  
 The motion passed 5–0. 
  
E-015/PA -24-198 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
 Chair Sieben  moved that the Commission do the following:  
 
1. Require Minnesota Power to supplement its p etition in this proceeding by  
October 8, 2024, to include the following required information:  
 
a. a detailed explanation of whether the pending acquisition of certain interests in Global Infrastructure Partners by BlackRock, Inc. requires Commission authorization under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 (2023), and if not, why not;  
 
b. all additional information required to comply with the filing requirements under 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 (2023) and Minn. R. 7825.1700 and 7825.1800 (2023) with 
respect to the pending acquisition of certain interests in Global Infrastructure 
Partners by Blac kRock, Inc.;  
 
c. a discussion of affiliated interest issues that may arise between ALLETE and companies held directly or indirectly in the portfolios of Canada Pension Plan Investment Board or BlackRock, Inc.  
 
3 | Page  2. Refer this matter to the Office of Administrative Hearings for a contested case and 
request an Administrative Law Judge’s Report with issues as ordered below.  
 
3. Order that the following issues be developed on the record:  
 
a. Are there any potential harms to the public interest from the proposed transaction, 
including in relation to cost or risk?   
b. Are there any potential benefits to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest from the proposed transaction?  
 
c. Considering all relevant factors and applicable law, is the proposed transaction 
consistent with the public interest?  
 
d. Are there regulatory requirements or commitments necessary to render the 
proposed transaction consistent with the public interest?  
 
e. How do relevant and related dockets pending before the Federal Energy Regulatory 
Commission, Public Service Commission of Wisconsin, and/or other state, federal or foreign government agencies impact the Commission’s consideration of the proposed transactio n? 
 
f. How will the Acquisition impact Minnesota Power’s union and non- union workforce  
and do the protections included in the acquisition proposal adequately protect that 
workforce?  
 
g. How will the acquisition impact Minnesota Power's ability to comply with the  
carbon -free standard under Minn. Stat. § 216B.1691 , including any modifications of 
plans associated with the Nemadji Trail Energy Center?  
 
4. Determine that it is necessary for the Department to obtain specialized technical professional investigative services pursuant to Minn. Stat. 216B.62, subd. 8 , to assist the 
Department in its review.  
 5. Request that the ALJ issue the r eport and r ecommendation not later than July 15, 2025, 
or before that date in the event of a settlement.  
 
6. Find that the m otions to intervene filed by ECC, CUB, LPI, IBEW, LIUNA Minnesota & 
North Dakota are deemed granted . 
 The motion passed 5 –0.
 
 
 
  
4 | Page  E-002/GR -10-971 
In the Matter of the Application of Xcel Energy for Authority to Increase Rates for Electric 
Service in the State of Minnesota  
 
E-002/GR -21-630  
In the Matter of the Application of Xcel Energy for Authority to Increase Rates for Electric 
Service in the State of Minnesota  
 
G-002/GR -21-678  
In the Matter of the Application of Xcel Energy for Authority to Increase Rates for Electric 
Service in the State of Minnesota  
 
E-002/M -21-815  
In the Matter of Xcel Energy’s Petition for Approval to return the Department of Energy’s 
fourteenth settlement payment to Minnesota electric customers  
 E-002/M -22-489  
In the Matter of Xcel Energy’s Petition for Approval to Return the Proceeds from the Sale of 348 acres of Land at Sherco to Electric Customers.  
 E,G-002/M -23-468  
In the Matter of Xcel Energy’s Report on the Operation and Performance of its 2022 Incentive 
Compensation Plan  
 
E,G-002/M -24-221  
In the Matter of Xcel Energy’s Petition for Approval of 2023 Annual Incentive Plan True -Up 
Report  
 
Commissioner Ham moved that the Commission:  
 
1. Approve Xcel’s proposed $21,152,331 2023 property tax refund for electric customers.  
 
2. Approve Xcel’s proposed ($1,183,910) 2023 property tax deferral for gas customers.  
 
3. Approve Xcel’s proposed ($24,841) 2022 property tax deferral for gas customers.  
 
4. Require Xcel to apply, on a monthly basis, the prime interest rate to the property tax refund through the month immediately preceding the billing cycle in which the 
Company issues the refund to ratepayers.  
 
5. Approve Xcel’s proposed $21,189,247 2023 capital true -up refund for electric customers.  
 
6. Require Xcel to apply, on a monthly basis, the prime interest rate to the capital true -up 
refund through the month immediately preceding the billing cycle in which the Company issues refunds to ratepayers.  
 
5 | Page  7. Approve Xcel’s proposed $5,038,765 net operating loss refund for electric customers.  
 
8. Require Xcel to apply, on a monthly basis, the prime interest rate to the net operating 
loss refund through the month immediately preceding the billing cycle in which the 
Company issues refunds to ratepayers.  
 
9. Accept Xcel’s annual Incentive Compensation Report.  
 
10. Approve Xcel’s proposed $1,671,277 2023 Annual Incentive Compensation refund for 
electric customers.  
 
11. Approve Xcel’s proposed $32,479 of 2023 Annual Incentive Compensation Refund for 
gas customers. (Xcel, DOC)  
 
12. Approve Xcel’s proposal to combine 2022 and 2023 annual incentive compensation gas refunds with 2022 and 2023 property tax deferrals.  
 
13. Require Xcel to apply, on a monthly basis, the prime interest rate to the 2023 electric annual incentive compensation refund through the month immediately preceding the billing cycle in which the Company issues refunds to ratepayers.  
 
14. Approve Xcel’s proposed proceeds from land sale refund amount of $5,643,638 for 
electric customers.  
 
15. Require Xcel to file a compliance filing within 10 days of the date of this order 
demonstrating that the Company’s refund recalculations reflect the changes approved herein.  
 16. Require Xcel to file a compliance filing, within 30 days after completing the refunds, that confirms their issuance.  
 
17. Require Xcel to file future comprehensive filings annually on July 1 in a new docket for all refunds: property tax, annual incentive compensation, capital true -up, and net 
operating loss.  
 The motion passed 5 -0. 
    
6 | Page  E-002/AA -22-179  
In the Matter of Xcel Energy’s Petition for Approval of its 2023 Annual Fuel Forecast and 
Monthly Fuel Cost Charges  
 
Commissioner Ham moved that the Commission:  
 
1. Accept Xcel’s 2023 Fuel Forecast True -Up Report.  
 
2. Approve Xcel’s proposed refund of $126 million to Minnesota ratepayers.  
 
3. Require that Xcel make a compliance filing with the total refund calculation within 
fourteen days of the date of this order.  
 
4. Require that Xcel include the following information about planned outages in future 
true -up petitions: unit, outage category, primary reason for planned outage, outage 
start and end dates, duration in days, reason for planned outage, description of actions  
taken during outage, and change in energy costs due to outage.  
 
5. Find that Xcel acted imprudently regarding the October 2023 outage at Prairie Island.  
 
6. Refer this matter to the Minnesota Office of Administrative Hearings for a contested 
case to determine the appropriate refund amount due to customers due to Xcel’s lack of 
prudence regarding the October 2023 outage at Prairie Island.  
 
7. Require that Xcel include interest using the U.S. Federal Reserve Prime Rate in any outage -related refund approved.  
 
The motion passed 5 –0. 
  E-142,002/SA -23-516 
In the Matter of the Joint Petition for Steele- Waseca Cooperative Electric to Provide  Service 
Under Section 216B.42.  
 Commissioner Sullivan moved that the Commission:  
 
1. Adopt the ALJ Report with the following modifications:  
 
a. Find that it is appropriate to consider both phase one and phase two of the facility 
because Core X is requesting permits from Bridgewater for both a “phase one” and 
“phase two” of its project at the same time and it is therefore appropriate to include both phases as the scope of customer operations.  
 
b. With respect to factor two, strike references in the ALJ Report to the ability of the power supply to meet other industrial park businesses.    
 
7 | Page  c. Reject Conclusions of Law 26, 28, 29 and 30 regarding factor five – Customer 
Preference.   Adopt a revised conclusion: NEW 28:   Core X’s stated preference is 
service by Steele -Waseca.    
 
2. Deny the Joint Petition for Steele -Waseca Cooperative Electric to Provide Service under 
Section 216B.42.  
 
The motion passed 4 –1 with Commissioner Tuma opposed.  
  E,G-002/CI -02-2034  
In the Matter of Investigation and Audit of Service Quality Reporting - Fraudwise Report;  
 E,G-002/M -12-383 
In the Matter of a Petition of Northern States Power Company d/b/a Xcel Energy for Approval of Amendments to its Natural Gas and Electric Service Quality Tariffs Originally Established in Docket No. E- 002,G- 002/CI -02-2034  
 Commissioner Means moved that the Commission:  
 
1. Require Xcel Energy to apply a direct credit, in order of oldest outstanding balance first, to accounts of customers who are unable to participate in Xcel’s proposed pilot program 
in Docket No. E -022/M -24-27, have a past due balance greater than $5,000,  have not 
otherwise received energy assistance, and have made a payment within the last 90 
days. Xcel will apply credits as follows:  
 Require Xcel to apply a $500 payment to customers that meet the above criteria and live within specified low -income census block groups starting with the census blocks with 
the lowest income.  
 2. Require Xcel to report every month from the date of the Order:  
 a. Details of amount credited to each customer  
 
b. Credit details of customer count  
 
c. Past -due details of customer count  
 
d. Count of customers receiving funds by Census Block Group  
 
e. Amount remaining of Distribution Under Performance Payment Penalty while the fund remains  
 
f. Total customers disconnected  
 
g. Number of reconnections by customer class (residential and non -residential)  
 
8 | Page  h. Number of customers receiving multiple disconnections  
 
3. Direct parties to discuss redistribution of the underperformance payments applied to 
customer bills and inﬂation adjustment to the underperformance penalty with any 
agreed -upon modiﬁcations included in the 2024 Quality of Service Plan report.  
 
The motion passed 5 –0. 
 
 
There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned.  
 
 APPROVED BY THE COMMISSION: February 19, 2025
